These files include data from Annex 3 EBSMs Data Tables.

rightsAnalysis.title: Section 19 of the Youth Criminal Justice Act: A look at the use of conferences across Canada
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Youth Criminal Justice Act (YCJA) came into force on April 1, 2003 to assist in reducing the notably high Canadian youth custody rate. The YCJA promotes youth rehabilitation and reintegration into society through diversion from the formal justice system and greater community involvement in responding to youth crime. It also promotes responsibility and accountability through measures that are proportionate to the seriousness of the offence and the youthâ€™s stage of development. In support of these goals, section 19 of the YCJA introduced conferences as a means to assist both decision makers and youth involved in the criminal justice system (CJS). Section 19 conferences provide an opportunity for various professionals and stakeholders, including the young person concerned and their family, to come together to discuss the matter in a more informal setting in order to formulate recommendations about the young personâ€™s case.

Despite the introduction of section 19 conferences almost 20 years ago, there has been little information gathered on the extent of their use, how they are being conducted, and the associated outcomes. In 2020, the Department of Justice Canada undertook a national survey to fill this knowledge gap. An invitation to complete the electronic survey was sent to provincial and territorial representatives of the Coordinating Committee of Senior Officials â€“ Youth Justice. All 13 jurisdictions completed the survey.

The focus of this research was to better understand how provinces and territories are using section 19 of the YCJA (and other related sections). This research also aimed to gain insight into ways of addressing the overrepresentation of Indigenous and racialized youth in the CJS.The focus of this research was to better understand how provinces and territories are using section 19 of the YCJA (and other related sections). This research also aimed to gain insight into ways of addressing the overrepresentation of Indigenous and racialized youth in the CJS. Many aspects of section 19 conferences were examined, including:

Extent of use of conferences;
Purposes and processes of conferences;
Benefits of conferences;
Challenges of conferences; and
Data collection, evaluations and impact assessments.
Results indicated that all jurisdictions convene section 19 conferences, with the exception of Quebec and the Yukon. Most jurisdictions reported having developed either rules, policies, guidelines and/or programs pertaining to the convening of conferences, although these varied widely.

Conferences were reported to be convened at all stages of the CJS, with most jurisdictions convening them at the post-charge/pre-finding of guilt, post-finding of guilt/pre-sentence and post-sentencing stages. Slightly fewer jurisdictions reported convening conferences at the pre-charge stage. Jurisdictions noted that conferences were convened for a variety of purposes, most notably as a means to attain advice on a sentencing plan or to assist in the process of developing a sentencing plan, to coordinate social services, to determine appropriate extrajudicial sanctions, as well as to determine conditions for judicial interim release (i.e., bail).

Jurisdictions described differing processes for convening section 19 conferences. Four jurisdictions reported having dedicated resources for organizing conferences. In terms of who convenes conferences, jurisdictions noted that various professionals may do so, such as provincial directors or delegates, probation officers, youth workers, mental-health workers, police officers, Crown prosecutors, Justices of the Peace, or defence counsels, among others. Further, several jurisdictions reported that conferences were convened by judges, which is consistent with section 41 of the YCJA.

Those who took part in a conference (as participants) also varied by jurisdiction, but generally included the youth, family or other support people, probation officers, social workers, child welfare representatives, mental health workers, school representatives, as well as Elders or an Indigenous representative. Other less frequently noted types of participants included police officers, Crown prosecutors, the defence counsels, educators, interpreters, as well as victims and their family and other support people of the victim.

Alberta was the only jurisdiction to report eligibility criteria to participate in a conference. These criteria pertained to youth and offence characteristics. However, a review of policy/guideline/program documents provided by other jurisdictions identified a number of situations or circumstances that lead to the consideration of a section 19 conference. These included, for example, complex cases where custody is considered or when dealing with chronic re-offending. Conversely, only the Northwest Territories prohibited the use of section 19 conferences in certain circumstances (i.e., when charges related to specific types of offences such as murder).

Notable benefits of section 19 conferences were reported, such as:

Increasing involvement and buy-in of youth in their case;
Helping address diverse and complex needs (e.g., youth who are under the jurisdictions of both child welfare services and the CJS, those with cognitive abilities);
Increasing collaboration between justice actors and between social systems for better case planning;
Providing an opportunity for restorative justice; and,
Leading to reduced charges and recidivism.
Further, many jurisdictions confirmed that conferences allowed accommodations and adaptions for diversity, which included accommodations specific to Indigenous identity, cultural and/or linguistic background, gender and lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, and asexual (LGBTQIA+) identities, mental health and/or addiction issues, in addition to accommodations for cognitive disabilities.

A number of challenges and areas for improvement pertaining to section 19 conferences were highlighted by jurisdictions. These included:

Scheduling, time requirements, and logistical issues (e.g., conflicting schedules, lack of dedicated coordinators; technological limitations around access to phones and internet);
Difficulties getting people to support and participate in conferences; and,
Limited availability of community programs, resources and supports for case planning.
Less than half of jurisdictions reported collecting some form of administrative data on various aspects of section 19 conferences (e.g., number, youth characteristics, purposes, participants, outcome and cost). Three jurisdictions (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and New Brunswick) reported having conducted an evaluation or impact assessment. Similar benefits and challenges as those reported in this study were found by these assessments.

Despite the widespread use of section 19 conferences across Canada, the current research has demonstrated that there are limited data collected across Canada on the use of section 19 conferences and their outcomes. However, the many benefits of section 19 conferences highlighted in this study provide support for further consideration of expanding the use of section 19 conferences across Canada. This could better support youth involved in the CJS and possibly help contribute to a reduction in the overrepresentation of Indigenous and racialized youth in custody.
rightsAnalysis.organization: Department of Justice Canada | MinistÃ¨re de la Justice Canada

rightsAnalysis.title: Staffing and Non-Partisanship Survey 2018
rightsAnalysis.description:
The SNPS is an important tool for understanding public servants' perceptions of the public service staffing system as well as their awareness of their legal rights and responsibilities regarding political activities.
The information gathered in the survey will be used to identify current and emerging trends at government-wide and organizational levels, to inform potential improvements to staffing policies and practices, and better target efforts to safeguard non-partisanship within the federal public service.
The survey will provide vital information to managers, human resources advisors and Deputies to improve staffing within their own organizations, and to the Public Service Commission (PSC) on the staffing system as a whole. The information will also be used to support reporting to Parliament via the PSC's Annual Report.

The survey is conducted every two years.

In an effort to make our datasets more easily understood and user-friendly, the PSC has created an accompanying descriptive video, outlining the variables, key considerations and providing an example and demonstration of how the dataset can be used. The video can be found at the following link [Staffing and Non-Partisanship Survey (video)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u4n1qwk7XZs).
rightsAnalysis.organization: Public Service Commission of Canada | Commission de la fonction publique du Canada

rightsAnalysis.title: Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) disability adjudication data
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services data set for Ontario Disability
Support Program (ODSP) adjudication contains ODSP disability adjudication
applications and their outcomes (decisions, decision dates, type of
disability).

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) Employment Supports Management System
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) Employment Supports Management
System (ESMS) uses portions of the Social Assistance Management System (SAMS)
dataset to facilitate employment supports management functions that are not
currently supported by the SAMS application. SAMS is a case management system
for social assistance clients.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Dental benefits for Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) clients
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services data set for the Ontario Dental
Association benefits contains information on Ontario Disability Support
Program (ODSP) clients in receipt of dental benefits. It includes:

  * claim number
  * procedure number
  * tooth code
  * service date
  * paid amount, etc.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) / Ontario Works field office satisfaction survey
rightsAnalysis.description:
These survey results contain staff satisfaction information from field offices
regarding the Service Delivery Model Technology (SDMT) system. SDMT is the
provincial application system that, until October 2014, supported the delivery
of social assistance under the Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) and
Ontario Works programs.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Labour Market Agreement for Persons with Disabilities (LMAPD) Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) survey data (individual level)
rightsAnalysis.description:
To improve the employment situation for Canadians with disabilities, the
Government of Canada provides funding through a Labour Market Agreement for
Persons with Disabilities (LMAPD) with the Government of Ontario.

The Ministry of Community and Social Services uses this yearly survey for
Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) clients for annual reporting to the
Government of Canada. The survey reports on a number of indicators about ODSP
income and employment supports.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Disability Adjudication Database
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Disability Adjudication Database (DAD) has incorporated integrated
workflows and file staging customized to the ministry's Disability
Adjudication Unit (DAU)'s business processes. It tracks what happens to a
referral for Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) benefits from the time
a disability determination package is received at the DAU. The database
follows the referral as it goes through the various stages of the adjudication
process, including appeals to the Divisional Court.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) / Ontario Works field office business process survey
rightsAnalysis.description:
These survey results track field office staff activities in the Service
Delivery Model Technology (SDMT) system, including: client inquiry,
preliminary assessment, client appointment, client interview and application,
eligibility determination, Disability Adjudication Unit (DAU) referral, grant
social assistance, participation requirements, financial processing, ongoing
case management, financial eligibility review, appeals, and ODSP employment
support.

SDMT is the system that, until October 2014, supported the delivery of social
assistance under the ODSP and Ontario Works programs.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

violations.name: Discriminatory Eligibility Rules
violations.description: Rules that disproportionately exclude disabled persons

rightsAnalysis.title: Ontario Disability Support Program cases and beneficiaries
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services reports the numbers of Ontario
Disability Support Program (ODSP) cases and beneficiaries (by family
structure), the number of children and Assistance for Children with Severe
Disabilities (ACSD) cases as of the end of month (April 2008 to present).

rightsAnalysis.title: Ontario social assistance rates
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services compiles various Ontario
Works/Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) rates (basic needs, shelter,
etc.) and rates for federal and provincial income security and tax benefit
programs.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Social assistance caseloads by Consolidated Municipal Service Manager/District Social Services Administration Board (CMSM/DSSAB) and First Nations (FN) delivery partner
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services reports monthly social
assistance caseloads by Consolidated Municipal Service Manager/District Social
Services Administration Board (CMSM/DSSAB) and First Nations delivery partner
for:

  * Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP)
  * Assistance for Children with Severe Disabilities (ACSD)
  * Ontario Works
  * Temporary Care Assistance (TCA)

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Social Assistance Caseloads
rightsAnalysis.description:
Data prior to April 1998 includes recipients of:

  * general welfare assistance
  * family benefits
  * foster care
  * handicapped children benefits

Data from April 1, 1998 onward includes recipients of:

  * Ontario Works
  * Ontario Disability Support Program
  * Temporary Care Assistance
  * Assistance for Children with Severe Disabilities

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Social Assistance Legacy Information System
rightsAnalysis.description:
The social assistance Legacy Information System (SALIS) contains an archive of
personal and financial information for all applicants and active recipients
of:  
â€¢ Ontario Works  
â€¢ Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP)  
â€¢ Assistance for Children with Severe Disabilities (ACSD).

This dataset was used for the delivery of social assistance prior to the
implementation of the Social Assistance Management System (SAMS). SAMS is a
case management system for social assistance clients.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Short Term Training Services (STTS) service provider survey data
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services evaluated the Short Term
Training Services (STTS) pilot with this one-time survey of Ontario Disability
Support Program (ODSP) employment support service providers who received
funding as part of the STTS pilot.

The purpose of the pilot was to provide ODSP employment supports clients with
access to labour-market oriented short-term training to improve clients'
overall employability and employment outcomes.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Social assistance operational indicators data set
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services reports monthly information on
operational indicators by Ontario Works Consolidated Municipal Service
Manager/District Social Services Administration Board (CMSM/DSSAB) and Ontario
Disability Support Program (ODSP) region/local office, in the following areas:

  * intake
  * case management workload
  * customer service
  * accountability
  * financial

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Social assistance operations performance report
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services compiles high priority
performance indicators, including indicators on:  
â€¢ intake  
â€¢ caseload  
â€¢ client outcomes  
â€¢ overpayments  
â€¢ suspensions  
â€¢ payments  
The ministry organizes the reports by Ontario Disability Support Program
(ODSP) local office and Ontario Works Consolidated Municipal Service
Manager/District Social Services Administration Board (CMSM/DSSAB).

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

rightsAnalysis.title: Social assistance program eligibility
rightsAnalysis.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services data set for social assistance
(SA) program eligibility contains information on SA clients that is used to
determine eligibility for social assistance programs (Ontario Works (OW),
Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP)). The dataset includes:  
â€¢ case characteristics  
â€¢ amount of allowances for which the benefit unit is eligible  
â€¢ actual shelter cost  
â€¢ aggregate income amount  
â€¢ employment earnings  
â€¢ aggregate asset amount  
â€¢ the outcome of eligibility determination

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

violations.name: Discriminatory Eligibility Rules
violations.description: Rules that disproportionately exclude disabled persons

rightsAnalysis.title: Transitional aged youth reporting
rightsAnalysis.description:
Transitional aged youth (TAY) reporting captures data for individuals in the
North Region 14 years of age and older who may transfer to adult developmental
services. It includes:

  * current service (group home, foster etc.)
  * fiscal and annual costs (where available)
  * confirmation status of adult developmental services eligibility
  * completion status of the Application for Developmental Services and Supports (ADSS) & Support Intensity Scale (SIS)
  * completion status of the Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) application

This reporting aids planning/forecasting for transitioning individuals.

issues.concern: Must ensure adequate standard of living for persons with disabilities

source.title: Section 19 of the Youth Criminal Justice Act: A look at the use of conferences across Canada
source.description:
The Youth Criminal Justice Act (YCJA) came into force on April 1, 2003 to assist in reducing the notably high Canadian youth custody rate. The YCJA promotes youth rehabilitation and reintegration into society through diversion from the formal justice system and greater community involvement in responding to youth crime. It also promotes responsibility and accountability through measures that are proportionate to the seriousness of the offence and the youthâ€™s stage of development. In support of these goals, section 19 of the YCJA introduced conferences as a means to assist both decision makers and youth involved in the criminal justice system (CJS). Section 19 conferences provide an opportunity for various professionals and stakeholders, including the young person concerned and their family, to come together to discuss the matter in a more informal setting in order to formulate recommendations about the young personâ€™s case.

Despite the introduction of section 19 conferences almost 20 years ago, there has been little information gathered on the extent of their use, how they are being conducted, and the associated outcomes. In 2020, the Department of Justice Canada undertook a national survey to fill this knowledge gap. An invitation to complete the electronic survey was sent to provincial and territorial representatives of the Coordinating Committee of Senior Officials â€“ Youth Justice. All 13 jurisdictions completed the survey.

The focus of this research was to better understand how provinces and territories are using section 19 of the YCJA (and other related sections). This research also aimed to gain insight into ways of addressing the overrepresentation of Indigenous and racialized youth in the CJS.The focus of this research was to better understand how provinces and territories are using section 19 of the YCJA (and other related sections). This research also aimed to gain insight into ways of addressing the overrepresentation of Indigenous and racialized youth in the CJS. Many aspects of section 19 conferences were examined, including:

Extent of use of conferences;
Purposes and processes of conferences;
Benefits of conferences;
Challenges of conferences; and
Data collection, evaluations and impact assessments.
Results indicated that all jurisdictions convene section 19 conferences, with the exception of Quebec and the Yukon. Most jurisdictions reported having developed either rules, policies, guidelines and/or programs pertaining to the convening of conferences, although these varied widely.

Conferences were reported to be convened at all stages of the CJS, with most jurisdictions convening them at the post-charge/pre-finding of guilt, post-finding of guilt/pre-sentence and post-sentencing stages. Slightly fewer jurisdictions reported convening conferences at the pre-charge stage. Jurisdictions noted that conferences were convened for a variety of purposes, most notably as a means to attain advice on a sentencing plan or to assist in the process of developing a sentencing plan, to coordinate social services, to determine appropriate extrajudicial sanctions, as well as to determine conditions for judicial interim release (i.e., bail).

Jurisdictions described differing processes for convening section 19 conferences. Four jurisdictions reported having dedicated resources for organizing conferences. In terms of who convenes conferences, jurisdictions noted that various professionals may do so, such as provincial directors or delegates, probation officers, youth workers, mental-health workers, police officers, Crown prosecutors, Justices of the Peace, or defence counsels, among others. Further, several jurisdictions reported that conferences were convened by judges, which is consistent with section 41 of the YCJA.

Those who took part in a conference (as participants) also varied by jurisdiction, but generally included the youth, family or other support people, probation officers, social workers, child welfare representatives, mental health workers, school representatives, as well as Elders or an Indigenous representative. Other less frequently noted types of participants included police officers, Crown prosecutors, the defence counsels, educators, interpreters, as well as victims and their family and other support people of the victim.

Alberta was the only jurisdiction to report eligibility criteria to participate in a conference. These criteria pertained to youth and offence characteristics. However, a review of policy/guideline/program documents provided by other jurisdictions identified a number of situations or circumstances that lead to the consideration of a section 19 conference. These included, for example, complex cases where custody is considered or when dealing with chronic re-offending. Conversely, only the Northwest Territories prohibited the use of section 19 conferences in certain circumstances (i.e., when charges related to specific types of offences such as murder).

Notable benefits of section 19 conferences were reported, such as:

Increasing involvement and buy-in of youth in their case;
Helping address diverse and complex needs (e.g., youth who are under the jurisdictions of both child welfare services and the CJS, those with cognitive abilities);
Increasing collaboration between justice actors and between social systems for better case planning;
Providing an opportunity for restorative justice; and,
Leading to reduced charges and recidivism.
Further, many jurisdictions confirmed that conferences allowed accommodations and adaptions for diversity, which included accommodations specific to Indigenous identity, cultural and/or linguistic background, gender and lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, and asexual (LGBTQIA+) identities, mental health and/or addiction issues, in addition to accommodations for cognitive disabilities.

A number of challenges and areas for improvement pertaining to section 19 conferences were highlighted by jurisdictions. These included:

Scheduling, time requirements, and logistical issues (e.g., conflicting schedules, lack of dedicated coordinators; technological limitations around access to phones and internet);
Difficulties getting people to support and participate in conferences; and,
Limited availability of community programs, resources and supports for case planning.
Less than half of jurisdictions reported collecting some form of administrative data on various aspects of section 19 conferences (e.g., number, youth characteristics, purposes, participants, outcome and cost). Three jurisdictions (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and New Brunswick) reported having conducted an evaluation or impact assessment. Similar benefits and challenges as those reported in this study were found by these assessments.

Despite the widespread use of section 19 conferences across Canada, the current research has demonstrated that there are limited data collected across Canada on the use of section 19 conferences and their outcomes. However, the many benefits of section 19 conferences highlighted in this study provide support for further consideration of expanding the use of section 19 conferences across Canada. This could better support youth involved in the CJS and possibly help contribute to a reduction in the overrepresentation of Indigenous and racialized youth in custody.

source.title: Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) / Ontario Works field office business process survey
source.description:
These survey results track field office staff activities in the Service
Delivery Model Technology (SDMT) system, including: client inquiry,
preliminary assessment, client appointment, client interview and application,
eligibility determination, Disability Adjudication Unit (DAU) referral, grant
social assistance, participation requirements, financial processing, ongoing
case management, financial eligibility review, appeals, and ODSP employment
support.

SDMT is the system that, until October 2014, supported the delivery of social
assistance under the ODSP and Ontario Works programs.

medium.name: Benefit Reductions
medium.description: Any reduction in disability or workers' compensation benefits

source.title: Social Assistance Caseloads
source.description:
Data prior to April 1998 includes recipients of:

  * general welfare assistance
  * family benefits
  * foster care
  * handicapped children benefits

Data from April 1, 1998 onward includes recipients of:

  * Ontario Works
  * Ontario Disability Support Program
  * Temporary Care Assistance
  * Assistance for Children with Severe Disabilities

medium.name: Discriminatory Eligibility Rules
medium.description: Rules that disproportionately exclude disabled persons

source.title: Social assistance program eligibility
source.description:
The Ministry of Community and Social Services data set for social assistance
(SA) program eligibility contains information on SA clients that is used to
determine eligibility for social assistance programs (Ontario Works (OW),
Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP)). The dataset includes:  
â€¢ case characteristics  
â€¢ amount of allowances for which the benefit unit is eligible  
â€¢ actual shelter cost  
â€¢ aggregate income amount  
â€¢ employment earnings  
â€¢ aggregate asset amount  
â€¢ the outcome of eligibility determination

medium.name: Benefit Reductions
medium.description: Any reduction in disability or workers' compensation benefits

source.title: Transitional aged youth reporting
source.description:
Transitional aged youth (TAY) reporting captures data for individuals in the
North Region 14 years of age and older who may transfer to adult developmental
services. It includes:

  * current service (group home, foster etc.)
  * fiscal and annual costs (where available)
  * confirmation status of adult developmental services eligibility
  * completion status of the Application for Developmental Services and Supports (ADSS) & Support Intensity Scale (SIS)
  * completion status of the Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) application

This reporting aids planning/forecasting for transitioning individuals.
